properties.name: Greyhound Bus Terminal
properties.description: "When the big Greyhound bus pulled into the Atlanta bus station that late Sunday morning of December 4, 1949, I knew I had to act as if I'd been here before. Be cool. At age fifteen, I was on my first trip more than five miles from my home" (13).  Additional link:https://www.greyhound.com/en/about/default.aspx  Image 1: October 1941 by Herbert H. Lee; Image 2: Cover of Andrews' memoir, illustrated by Benny Andrews.

properties.name: Rich's Department Store
properties.description: “Of all the buildings and places he [Harvey] pointed out to me on this day while we walked around a nearly deserted Atlanta, I was most impressed by the department store Rich’s with its ramp running several stories overhead in connecting a building on each side of the street” (25). Andrews later took a job at Rich’s, after he worked at Aidmore Hospital and Emile’s French Cafe (131), working “in the kitchen of the (white) employees’ cafeteria . . . it was above the Magnolia Tea Room . . . where all the colored help worked dressed like Hattie McDaniel and fellow slaves in Gone With The Wind” (163) . Rich’s had a segregated dining room for its customers and a separate cafeteria for its black employees while Andrews worked there. Inasmuch, Rich’s would not hire Val, Andrews’ sister, “because she didn’t look ‘maidish,’ or ‘colored enough’” (145). Additional links: http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/articles/business-economy/richs-department-store and http://www.returntorichs.org/  Image 1:

properties.name: Butler Street YMCA
properties.description: Once Andrews arrived in Atlanta, he caught a cab ride to the YMCA he had been told about back home: “the man turned off Auburn Avenue onto Butler Street and rather than putting me out at the jailhouse, dropped me off about middle of the block right in front of the YMCA. Thanking the man, I got out of the truck and stood on the sidewalk in front of the YMCA staring up at it . . . It happened more than once that someone from some small Georgia town would migrate to Atlanta and discover the Butler Street Y, return home and spread the word, or 'preach the gospel,' about it, The Avenue, and the city to his peers. Thus forming an underground railroad, or 'Greyhound Highway,' from that specific town to the Butler Street Y” (17, 62). The Butler Street Y became a sort of safe haven for big city opportunities for many rural-born, young ,black men. Additional links: http://sweetauburn.us/ymca.htm and http://www.ajc.com/news/news/local/butler-street-ymca-faces-severe-financial-crisis-p/nQSjw/

properties.name: Aunt Polly's Apartment
properties.description: “After boarding the bus on Auburn Avenue we got off way out near the end of the line on Hunter Street (now Martin Luther King, Jr., Drive, named for a man born on Auburn Avenue) just past Booker T. Washington High School and right before an overhead train trestle. Here we took a path leading up the embankment and walked for about five minutes along the railroad path before turning off onto another dirt path. This path ran through a thin undergrowth taking us to the end of the paved Holderness Street where lived Aunt Polly (Mama’s sister) and her daughter, Geraldine (our first cousin) and husband, Almoore, and their two children” (22). Image 1: “New Zoot Suit” by Benny Andrews.

properties.name: The Avenue
properties.description: Early on in his memoir, Andrews depicts Auburn Avenue as the economic and cultural center of black Atlanta. Noting that most of the businesses located on “The Avenue” were owned by black people, Andrews sees a new level of racial freedom and pride than what he ever experienced in rural Georgia.“Later, we walked down Auburn Avenue where even more proudly Harvey began pointing out to me all the colored-owned establishments on, and just off, The Avenue . . . Down here within short distance of the Y were the insurance companies, Atlanta Life and North Carolina Mututal; the Citizens Trust Bank; the Atlanta Daily World daily newspaper; ‘The Good’ WERD radio station; the nightclubs, the Royal Peacock (formerly The Top Hat), the Poincaina and the AmVets; two hotels, the Royal and the Savoy; a doctors’ office building; several rooming houses; Blake’s Business and Apex Beauty colleges; Yates and Milton Drugstore; lawyers’ offices; Big Bethel A.M.E., Wheat Street and Ebenezer Baptist Churches, an

properties.name: Joe's Restaurant (location?)
properties.description: “We stopped on The Avenue in a restaurant called ‘Joe’s,’ a popular eating place for the residents of the Y” . . . It was here at Joe's on Auburn Avenue that for the first time I ate a meal in a restaurant" (26). Image 1: “Big Eating Treat” illustration by Benny Andrews.

properties.name: The Royal Theater (Odd Fellows Building)
properties.description: “The theatre, the Royal, was just around the corner from the Y and just a door or two down from Yates and Milton Drugs . . . But what I remembered more than the main feature was the newsreel. An all-colored (Negro) newsreel. I never knew such existed. Around the previous Thanksgiving the dancer, Bill Robinson (‘Bojangles’), had died . . . and this particular newsreel opened showing his funeral in Harlem, New York City, where the parade route and church were overflowing with people . . . Yet what I remember most of all about sitting there in the orchestra of the Royal that night was not the screen itself, but listening to the people laugh as loud and as long as they wanted to without a white owner’s head popping through the door to shush them” (31). Additional links: http://www.theoddfellowsbuildings.com/more_history.htm

properties.name: Yates and Milton Drug Store (Odd Fellows Building)
properties.description: “After leaving the theater we stopped in Yates and Milton and for the first time I sat at a table in a drugstore where I had my first milkshake, called ‘Malt-A-Plenty’ . . . we met a group of young boys walking down the street singing loudly the song, ‘That Lucky Old Sun’ . . . I remember walking up the steps of the Y thinking that here in Atlanta lived a world of colored folks who had many things and did many things they wanted to without white folks’ approval, or even knowledge” (32). Image 1: vintage postcard, 1912; Image 2: same view of Odd Fellows Building, circa 2005.

properties.name: Emory University
properties.description: “Arriving at Emory by city bus that morning shorly before eight o-clock, Mitch, before going to the kitchen, left me off at the personnel office. In here I was handed an application form from behind a desk by a pretty lady behind a typewriter who with a smile told me to ‘fill it out’ . . . All of my previous jobs (mainly working in fields, orchards, and woods) never required filling out anything paper. Just showing up each day ready to work and, weather permitting, working hard from sun to sun was application enough” (37). Image 1: quad of Emory, circa 2010.

properties.name: The Peachtree Theaters: the Roxy, the Rialto, and the Fox
properties.description: “These  were all the downtown, white, movie theaters . . . I found it hard to believe these were the same movie theaters whose opening and changing of films I’d followed religiously for years in The Atlanta Constitution. All of these movie theaters I knew about long before coming to the city for years in Madison having taken from the Constitution each day and saved Atlanta’s movies’ advertising and scheduling pages” (42). Additional links: http://www.rialtocenter.org/about/history.html and http://foxtheatre.org/the-fox-story/ and http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/10331 Image 1: The Roxy Theater was built in 1926, renamed the Roxy Theatre in 1938, and demolished in 1972 to make way for Atlanta's seventy-story Westin Peachtree Plaza Hotel; Image 2: The Rialto Theater 1940, premiere of “Who Killed Aunt Maggie?”; Image 3: Construction of Westin Peachtree Plaza, 1973; Image 4: The Fox Theater, March 1956.

properties.name: Ebenezer Baptist Church
properties.description: Many young newcomers to the city of Atlanta immediately sought community and belonging through the church upon their arrival. Andrews attends the Ebenezer Baptist Church with a friend from the Y one Sunday, explaining that it was "a common habit among most of the Y's newly arrived until they learned how to sleep late on the Sabbath without guilt" (62). At the time that Andrews attended the Ebenezer service, it was pastored by Reverend Martin Luther King, Sr. Andrews also notes that the most "recognizable-on-sight church" was Big Bethel A.M.E. (also (where Andrews’ friend, Ray, claimed he would attempt the finale of his dare-devil show), while the most popular church as Wheat Street Baptist. Image 1: Ebenezer Baptist Church circa 1950; Image 2: Rev. Martin Luther King, Sr., 1981; Image 3: Big Bethel A.M.E. circa 1945; Image 4: Wheat Street Baptist, circa 1945.

properties.name: Aidmore Convalescent Home for Children
properties.description: Andrews’ first job in Atlanta, working as an orderly for the boys’ ward. Here, Andrews learned the hierarchy of labor and how race is positioned through labor. “My daily hours at Aidmore were from 7:00 A.M. to 5:00 P.M., including an hour for lunch . . . [I was the] one who did everything the nurses were above doing, meaning the menial, manual and ‘dirty’ work . . . Yet out of necessity many whites did perform nigger work, instinctively causing them to lose the respect of the world, thus becoming known as ‘po’ white trash,’ the forerunner of the ‘redneck’” (48, 51). Image 1: “Children’s Ward” illustration by Benny Andrews; Image 2: 918 Peachtree St., June 2013.

properties.name: Atlanta City Hall
properties.description: In Andrews’s “Atlanta years,” Herman Talmadge was the Governor of Georgia, “ruling from the roost of the state capitol building rising up just a short way over from the Y” (154). Andrews’s black community in which he grew up had always considered the Talmadge family and select politicians from Mississippi and Louisiana “as being ‘the Nazis of the South’” (154). Another connection for Andrews: Mr. Dryer, Aidmore Hospital’s hiring manager, sends him to City Hall to get a blood test to qualify working in the Aidmore Convalescent Home for Children (44-45). Additional link: http://www.atlantaga.gov/index.aspx?page=409 Image 1: Women posing in front of City Hall circa 1950; Image 2: City Hall, 2009.

properties.name: The Cameo and The Central Movie Theaters
properties.description: The Cameo and Central were all-white movie houses on Peachtree. Being a film aficionado, Andrews spent much of his time there, sneaking into the theaters and passing as a white boy: “. . . early that afternoon I walked up to Peachtree and broke the law. Unlawfully entering the for-whites-only Cameo Theater to see The Three Musketeers . . . I continued my lawless rampage by going next door to the Central and seeing another double feature” (45).  Image 1: Cameo Theatre circa 1945; Image 2: Cameo Theatre circa 1943; Image 3: Central Theater circa 1954.

properties.name: #3 West Hunter busline
properties.description: Andrews is confronted by a “white lady” on a bus in the black part of town; although there are open seats at the front of the bus, she tells Andrews to “‘Move back, Boy!’” Andrews reflects that “I knew what she meant and, trained for such occasions, wordlessly got up and moved back to an empty seat [. . .] ‘Boy, you move on, on to the back!’ I was still sitting too close for her comfort . . . and power” (53). Andrews articulates the distance that accompanies the difference that is required to maintain racial domination. Image 1: “Move” illustration by Benny Andrews.

properties.name: Booker T. Washington High School
properties.description: Andrews attended evening high school at Booker T. Washington High to obtain his high school diploma. The black community of Atlanta took full advantage of the opportunity to finish their schooling: “The evening school (carrying all twelve grades as did the day school) consisted of several hundred adults coming back to earn their elementary and high school diplomas” (67).

properties.name: The House of Tragedy (location?)
properties.description: Andrews gives example of how the American Dream is a dangerous goal and rarely actually fulfills individuals, especially in the black community of Atlanta: “The Tragedy involved one of the night school’s most popular instructors whose daytime job I don’t recall but who, living just a few blocks away from school, was prosperous enough to keep a fashionable family in a fashionable house in a fashionable neighborhood. That’s why no one understood when the night before this fashion plate . . . [s]tayed home and shot and killed his fashionable family (a wife and two (or four?) children) and then himself” (69).

properties.name: Amos’s Drugstore
properties.description: Andrews completes what he deems a rite of passage into manhood when he buys condoms for himself; notably, though, he goes to a drugstore across town from his usual Yates and Milton Drugs, where a male employee was working the pharmaceutical counter. While Andrews wanted to remain anonymous in his purchasing of the condoms, the indication of his “final step in becoming a real man” had to be public: “A rubber had to season, or ‘sit,’ in the wallet. This meant that after weeks, months . . . years . . . of being sat upon, the rubber made a very visible impression, or ‘imprint,’ in the wallet. This whenever pulling out one’s wallet in public this imprint could easily be seen, and ‘impress,’ letting all happening to see that here was a man’s man, a man with a rubber” (71-72). Additional links: http://lat34north.com/HistoricMarkers/MarkerDetail.cfm?KeyID=060-WE10 Image 1: present-day historic landmark of Amos’s Drugstore; Image 2: close-up of landmark.

properties.name: Tavern on the corner of Auburn and Piedmont
properties.description: Frequented by old Enoch, a handyman at Aidmore Hospital; Andrews would listen to Enoch and his friend talk about baseball and the Negro Major Leagues (75-76).

properties.name: Atlanta Daily World
properties.description: The Atlanta Daily World, “the local black paper . . . whose office was straight down from the Y and a couple of doors off Butler on The Avenue” (79),  along with the Atlanta Constitution and the Atlanta Journal were the major daily newspapers that Andrews followed in Atlanta. Additional links: http://atlantadailyworld.com/ and http://sweetauburn.us/dailyworld.htm  Image: Office of Atlanta Daily World, est. circa 1955

properties.name: Grady Hospital Nursing Home (SCHOOL?) for the Colored
properties.description: “The Y was a beehive of activity. Weekend dances were frequently held in the gym but seldom did any Y roomers attend these. The dance attracting the Y’s occupants was the one given every Friday night just a few blocks over at the Grady Hospital Nursing Home for the Colored. Over the years several marriages were to occur between Grady’s nurses and occupants of the Y as a result of these dances” (80). Additional links: http://homer.gsu.edu/blogs/library/2010/02/24/african-american-labor-history-grady-hospital-school-of-nursing-records/  Image: Advertisement for Grady Hospital Schools of Nursing, circa 1945

properties.name: Meeting Officer Strickland
properties.description: “It was at the Y that I saw my first black policeman. Strickland . . . I saw him, often in uniform as he, along with the rest of Atlanta’s black policemen, daily dressed for duty here in the basement of the building where they kept their lockers because they were not allowed to dress . . . in the same dressing room with the white policemen (85). Additionally, Andrews notes, the black policemen of Atlanta were only permitted to arrest black citizens. “And, man, some of these black policemen were said to be mean mothers on the black” (85).

properties.name: The Savoy Hotel
properties.description: “On weekends, especially Saturday nights, the Savoy, its front facing Auburn Avenue, did a brisk business. Some of these nights business got so brisk with males and females checking into the hotel for one night--or one hour only--that oftentimes in taking their ‘quick naps’ these guests in such a hurry to get to dreamland would forget to pull down the window shades” (85). Additional links: http://www.nabhood.net/home/index.php/about-us/history-of-black-owned-hotels and http://sweetauburn.us/herndon.htm Image 1: Sketch of Herndron Building, which held the Savoy in teh 1950’s.

properties.name: Ponce De Leon Ballpark
properties.description: Before their official start to the professional baseball season, the MLB Brooklyn Dodgers came to play a three-game series with the local AA Minor League Atlanta Crackers (an all-black team) in 1949 and 1950. Andrews describes the 1949 series: “in order to see the Dodgers’ two black players, Jackie Robinson and Roy Campanella, black Atlanta turned out en masse [. . .] most blacks came dressed in their finest wear and created in the ballpark’s colored section a gala, a picnic, a carnival, and a party atmosphere all in one” (86). Of the 1950 series, however, Andrews most vividly remembers a “little black girl standing in the aisle of the ballpark crying . . . and bleeding all over her new Easter dress” after she was hit in the head by an object thrown by “one of a gang of whites” throwing debris into the colored section (89). Additional links: http://atlantatimemachine.com/misc/ballpark_pc4.htm Image 1:  Ballpark with Sears Roebuck building in background, 1942; Image 2: Aerial view of ba

properties.name: Bus stop on Peachtree St.
properties.description: While the white workers at Aidmore Hospital “acted almost humanly toward coloreds” inside the building, outside all sense of recognition and cordiality fell away. Waiting for the bus on Peachtree St., “[t]he whites and coloreds stood on separate sides of the bus stop sign, even” (103). Image 1: “Dividing Line” illustration by Benny Andrews.

properties.name: Newsstand and Bookstore on Peachtree
properties.description: Andrews had few friendly relationships with white people. One such cordial example, though, was with a white newsstand/bookstore owner. “(Even whites would nice to coloreds in public if the coloreds were buying from them.)” Andrews notes that during the many hours he spent in that store, he and the owner got to know one another on sight and “were forever discussing reading materials while I browsed” (103). Image 1: Front of Muse’s Mens department store, located directly across the street from the newsstand Andrews frequented, 1952; Image 2: Same building and angle, 2004; Image 3: “Book Worm” illustration by Benny Andrews.

properties.name: Peachtree and Ivy Streets Houses (location? Ivy renamed to Peachtree Center)
properties.description: Walking back to the Y from his work at Aidmore Hospital one day, Andrews experienced a moment of intense sexual awareness between himself and a white woman. “[O]n the corner of Peachtree Street and Ivy, began a row of homes, all-white residences . . . In walking past these houses I happened to glance to my left and directly into an open window of one” (104). Through the window, he saw a white woman looking into a mirror, putting on lipstick. Andrews describes this woman as very beautiful, with long, dark hair, “wearing no blouse, or top . . . nor brassiere” (104). Andrews froze, but the woman smiled at him, looking straight into his eyes. Andrews acknowledges that a “deep down fear of this being a ‘white’ woman and I knew I had better not get caught ‘looking’ at a naked one or I was as good as dead” (104). Even as a teenager, Andrews understood how the South guards the purity and sanctity of Southern white womanhood.

properties.name: Jewish Deli
properties.description: Andrews recalls other non-dominant minority business owners on The Avenue: “I remember the only Jewish delicatessen on the Avenue, right around the corner from the Y and directly across the street from Yates and Milton Drugs” (116). Two brothers, both having “pale white skin,” owned the shop. “Other than themselves,” Andrews notes, “all workers in the place were colored” (117). The Jewish deli was a great meeting place for people on The Ave--the food was cheap and good, and “[t]he brothers would even let you sign tabs,” signaling their trust in the local black community (117).

properties.name: Grady Housing Projects
properties.description: Andrews first frequented the Grady Housing Projects in the spring of 1950, when he and his brother Benny would go and meet a couple girls who lived there. Later on, Benny and Andrews were “‘rocked’ out of [the projects] by a gang of stone-throwing young males” (121).  Image 1: Aerial view of Grady Homes circa 1940;  Image 2: Grady Projects/Grady Homes circa 2000;  Image 3: Video of photo slide show of Grady Projects being demolished in 2005 to be rebuilt as Ashley Auburn Pointe “mixed-use community”

properties.name: Marie's House (near Pittman Park) (Location??)
properties.description: Marie, a girl Andrews courted for a time in 1950, lived “in southwest Atlanta near Pittman Park, a then recently built city public park for coloreds” (123). Andrews would visit Marie each Sunday evening, when she was permitted to “receive company.” Also on Sunday evenings, many other members of the neighborhood flocked to Marie’s house “to ‘watch the tube’,” as Marie’s father possessed the only television on the block. Because of all the people around, Andrews “first learned to hate television” at Marie’s house.

properties.name: Piedmont Park
properties.description: A whites-only park in the 1950’s, Andrews would sneak into it after midnight with his white girlfriend, Nancee, to “play” and have sex, “wallowing in the weeds all over this park and enjoying every moment” (129). Image 1: View of midtown Atlanta from Piedmont Park, circa 2010; Image 2: Postcard of bathhouse and poolside of Piedmont Park, circa 1950.

properties.name: Tiger Flowers Dr House (location??)
properties.description: Harvey (Andrews’ brother), Baylock (another resident of the Y), and Porter (a WWII veteran) moved from the Butler Street YMCA rented a house on Tiger Flowers Drive, “a street named after the first colored World Middleweight Champion who was from Camilla, Georgia, via Atlanta” (138). On Christmas of 1950, Andrews had his first taste of alcohol at this house with Harvey, who had “put a shot of something liquor-tasting in egg nog and handed it to me” (138).

properties.name: Fort Valley State College
properties.description: Located near Macon, Benny (Andrews’ brother) attended school at Fort Valley State College during Andrews’ “Atlanta years.” Additional link: https://www.flickr.com/search/?w=36222865@N07&q=fort%20valley%20state%20college Image 1: Huntington Hall, after its refurbishment in the early 2000’s, one of the original buildings of the college

properties.name: City of Marietta
properties.description: Benny, Andrews’ brother, took a job in Marietta “(pronounced ‘Mayetta’ by most)” at an “old and established Southern restaurant that catered to the town’s elite whites. To get to work up there, Benny had to take an early morning bus and wouldn’t return to the Y until late each day” (141). Image 1: Main streets of downtown Marietta, circa 2000.

properties.name: Phyllis Wheatley YWCA
properties.description: “Shortly before [Sister] arrived [in Atlanta], Benny, just up from college, and I (Harvey was at work) went to find Sister a place in Atlanta to stay. Our looking took us to the Phyllis Wheatley YWCA, located in Northeast Atlanta on, or near, Boulevard Avenue (but since moved to a new building over on the Westside). The only things I can remember about this YWCA were the building being much smaller, less sturdy and less attractive than the Butler Street Men’s Y; instead of males there were females all over the premises; and, more than anything else, Benny and I asking at the desk to see ‘Miss Phyllis Wheatley.’ Told politely by the female desk clerk that Miss Wheatley wasn’t available (having died 166 years earlier), Benny and I proceeded to register Sister (144). Additional links: http://www.ywcaatlanta.org/history  Image 1: Postcard of Phyllis Wheately YWCA, est. circa 1938; Image 2: Same image, photo taken 2008.

properties.name: Grady Hospital
properties.description: Birthplace of Andrews’ youngest brother, Gregory (Greg). All of the other Andrews children were born at home in Madison, GA, “by midwife, Grandmama Jessie” (146).  Image 1: View of Grady Memorial Hospital from Grady Homes (Grady Projects) and downtown skyline, photographed in 1957.

properties.name: Morehouse College
properties.description: Known as “the House,” and being a “brain” school (150), Andrews’ younger brother, Joe Louis, attended Morehouse for a year “where he made the football team and played one season,” before dropping out to work to support his wife and family (146). Joe was the family athlete and made the Andrews very proud through his other passionate endeavors: he joined the Air Force and “played four years of service sports”;  took a job in New York with IBM; started a successful restaurant business in Atlanta; became a civil-rights activist and joined the Black Muslims; and finally took work as a newspaper reporter before he was killed in an drunk-driving auto accident (an event which itself is suspicious, according to Andrews) (147). Image 1: Photo of the quad of Morehouse College, circa 2005.

properties.name: Clark University (Clark College)
properties.description: Known as the “party” school; along with Morehouse and Morris Brown, Clark was a fixture in the black community of Atlanta. Image 1:  Photo of hallmark building of Clark Atlanta University (Clark College and Atlanta University in 1988), circa 2000.

properties.name: Morris Brown University (College)
properties.description: Known as the “jock” school; along with Morehouse and Clark, Morris Brown was a fixture in the black community of Atlanta. Its sports teams and competitions were particularly kept up on and celebrated. Image 1: Recent photo of campus of Morris Brown, date unknown.

properties.name: David T. Howard High School
properties.description: A local Atlanta high school that offered both day and evening school to the black public. Andrews, an evening school student, wanted very badly to be a day school attendee. He almost got enrolled in “DTH” day high school, but his parents did not live in the district to qualify him (149).

properties.name: YMCA Poolroom
properties.description: “Directly across the aisle from the Y’s front desk in a glass and wood enclosure was the poolroom, consisting of three tables, each with nearby built-into-the-wall bench where I sat for hours . . . years . . . watching the game of pool. (The real pool shooters, or sharks, shot a few doors down on The Avenue in the big, dark, and smoky poolroom where went on a lot of illegal betting)” (149). In the Y’s poolroom, Andrews met many students from the other local high school, David T. Howard.   Image 1: “YMCA” Pool, illustration by Benny Andrews.

properties.name: Georgia Tech
properties.description: Andrews, being “a sports fiend,” followed all college sports team across the country, both black and white. “It wasn’t considered cool for a colored fellow to follow too closely Southern racially segregated sports,” but Andrews still kept close track of the Georgia Tech football team, remembering in particular their record of 1951 (153).  Image 1: Recent photo of Georgia Tech’s famous bell tower, date unknown.

properties.name: “The Good” WERD Radio Station
properties.description: “The music of the hour was Rhythm and Blues, R&B (sold on discs known in the white world as ‘race records’), earlier day ‘Soul.’ The all-colored radio station on The Avenue, ‘The Good’ WERD, carried these sounds much of the day and night” (155). Andrews notes that there were two white stations that played some R&B: WGST’s disc jockey, Zena Sears, played “nigger music” at night, and a Decatur station’s disc jockey Jack The Bellboy played even more R&B than Sears (155). Additional links: http://aafa.galileo.usg.edu/aafa/view?docId=ead/aarl90-008-ead.xml;query=;brand=default and http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/articles/arts-culture/werd Image 1: WERD radio station on Auburn Avenue, circa 1990; Image 2: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. outside the S.C.L.C. offices inAtlanta. WERD 860 is in the background; Image 3: Civil Rights leader and former Mayor of Atlanta Andrew Young talks about WERD

properties.name: The Royal Peacock (and The Poinciana)
properties.description: Atlanta had many music venues, being the bedrock of R&B and soul music in the 1950’s. “Some, for example, were the Royal Peacock and, just across the street on the next corner of The Avenue, The Poinciana . . . The Peacock was undoubtedly the best known of Atlanta’s colored night clubs but The Poinciana was practically ‘The Prince of the Blues,’ home of Atlanta’s top bluesman, Billy Wright (156). Andrews reflects the genealogy of blues music here, noting that Billy Soul preceded Little Richard and James Brown (156). Additional links: http://sweetauburn.us/peacock.htm Image 1: Sketch of Royal Peacock as it was circa 1950; Image 2: Photo of Royal Peacock, circa 1950;  Image 3: Corner view of Royal Peacock, circa 2010.

properties.name: Decatur Street
properties.description: While the “original” father of soul music, Billy Wright, got his start on Decatur Street, “Atlanta’s Beale Street, at the 81 Theater (Atlanta’s Apollo),” it was also known for other aspects of its history. “Decatur Street was loaded down with dives, juke joints, and honky-tonks where a lot of blues singing (and everything else) went on both indoors and on the street. Many years earlier Decatur Street was filled with black whorehouses while right around the corner on Courtland Street were the white whorehouses. The black and white pimps often got together to swap samples. Yet by 1950 Decatur Street had tamed down considerably but still had its ‘spots,’ along with its ‘sin street’ reputation” (156). Image 1: Downtown Atlanta at Decatur Street and Peachtree, April 12, 1948;  Image 2: Bailey’s 81 Theater, 1958

properties.name: The Auditorium (Atlanta Municipal Auditorium)
properties.description: “At least once a month a big name came to perform at the City Auditorium (a short walk from The Avenue). It was at the Auditorium where I saw Little Esther with the Johnny Otis Band. Also, here I saw Ruth Brown doing her ‘When Tear Drops Start to Fall’ number. Many other R&B performers came here (Arthur Prystock, Bo Didley, Wyonna Harris, The Ravens, Louis Jordan, Gatemouth Brown, Ivory Joe Hunter, to name a few) but at times the Auditorium could be dangerous to one’s health as a few people went to these concerts mainly to get drunk and fight” (159). Image 1: Atlanta Municipal Auditorium, est. circa 1950; Image 2: Dahlberg Hall (formerly the Auditorium), 2004.

properties.name: Westview Cemetery
properties.description: An all-white cemetery on Hunter Street, near Mozley Park, that “was eventually integrated underground” (159). Additional link: http://www.westviewcemetery.com/history.php Image 1: WBGE entering Westview Cemetery, 1947; Image 2: Similar photo position, 2008.

properties.name: Mozley Park
properties.description: Located “farther out” on Hunter Street, Mozely Park was a public city park only for whites. Later on, however, it transitioned to a colored park, as blacks were buying out the area houses (159). Image 1: Mozley Park Pavillion, est. circa 2010.

properties.name: Hunter Street
properties.description: “Atlanta Westside’s nearest answer to Auburn Avenue was Hunter Street with its Morris Brown College overpass, Paschall Brothers restaurant, Williams Tavern, Hunter Street Rib House, Amos Drugstore, Sellers Brothers Funeral Home, Ashby Movie Theater, and churches. But most of all Hunter Street was known for its colored homes and the farther out this street one travelled the nicer were the houses” (159). Among these nicer homes was the house that belonged to Graham Jackson, “the black Navy Chief Petty Officer pictured in Life Magazine crying while playing the accordion on the day after the death of President Franklin D. Roosevelt when the body was carried to the train at Warm Springs, Georgia, where he died on April 12, 1945” (159). Hunter Street was renamed to Martin Luther King Jr. Dive in the 1970s. Image 1: Hunter Street, 1969; Image 2: Life Magazine photo of Graham Jackson

properties.name: Dixie Hill
properties.description: Andrews remarks that “the black elite of the day lived a bit north of here [Hunter Street] in a section called ‘Dixie Hill,’ beginning way out Simpson Street. Out in Dixie Hill was the Lincoln Country Club where only members and their guests were allowed and which also carried live entertainment” (159-60).

properties.name: Washington Park
properties.description: Andrews and his friend Alvin’s usual spot for “girl hunting,” though often unsuccessful. Here, Alvin convinced Andrews to smoke so that they looked cooler to girls passing by--“and thus began my smoking career which was destined to last nineteen years before finally ending,” Andrews remarks (160).

properties.name: “The Kalahajee” Apartment Complex (location ??)
properties.description: “Built between Hunter and Simpson Streets and before Dixie Hill,” Andrews visited the basement of this complex once, which served as an “entertainment center with restaurant and open bar” (160). Andrews went to see Billy Wright sing; on that night, Andrews also noticed the attending crowd: “Present were several whites, which I’d seen at the Royal Peacock, white men and their white women, or white men with colored women. But here at the Kalahajee was the first time publicly I’d seen white women with colored men!” (160).

properties.name: Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church
properties.description: Andrews’ sister, Val, was married in 1952; Andrews gave her away to her future husband, William Westbury. What Andrews remembers most about Val’s wedding though was how  he “was first made aware of and introduced to Atlanta’s small, but tightly knit, colored Catholic community” (171). “Up until this point,” Andrews admits, “I had thought all Catholics were white, Spanish speaking, or Jews” (171). Additional link: http://lourdesatlanta.org/history/ and http://www.archatl.com/ministries/obcm/

properties.name: Atlanta Armed Forces Induction Center (Fort Gillem)
properties.description: In the late summer of 1952 Andrews joined the Air Force. The military first bussed out new enlistees to Atlanta’s Armed Forces Induction Center. Here, to his great surprise, Andrews remarks, “for the first time I fully realized that colored folks were truly a ‘minority.’ At the induction center that day there were less than twenty coloreds and, I feel sure, way over a hundred whites. Many of these whites (all males) were from the Atlanta area but (and shocking for me to hear at the time) not a single one of the many I asked had ever heard of Auburn Avenue. Upon hearing this, it seemed likely I had lived all my time in Atlanta in a vacuum” (176). Image 1: Fort Gillem entrance, est. circa 2010.
